turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Sexual orientation in the United States military.
turn.2: On October 27, 2011, the Servicemembers Legal Defense Network (SLDN) had brought suit in federal court in Massachusetts on behalf of several military servicemembers and veterans in same-sex marriages.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The benefits at issue in that case, "McLaughlin v. Panetta", included medical and dental benefits, basic housing and transportation allowances, family separation benefits, visitation rights in military hospitals, and survivor benefit plans.
turn.6: On June 27, the federal judge hearing the case asked the parties to explain by July 18 why the logic that found "Windsor" unconstitutional did not apply to that definition as well.
turn.7: Did they respond to the lawsuit?
turn.8: On July 18, the Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group BLAG, which had defended DOMA and the restrictive definitions of marriage acknowledged that "[t]he Supreme Court recently resolved the issue of DOMA Section 3's constitutionality" but took no position on the other statutes except to say that the constitutionality of those definitions "remains open".
turn.10: The Department of Justice told the court that it would not defend those statutes.
turn.11: Was there any other responses or changes made?
turn.12: BLAG asked to withdraw from a similar lawsuit in federal court in California, "Cooper-Harris v. United States", on July 22.
